entry.string:
# lines that start with the # sign are ignored
# but the next line is a line of code: print "hello world"
# you can execute this line by pressing command-return when you have your cursor on it.
# (you can also select multiple lines that you'd like to execute and then press command-return to execute them all together).
print "hello" print "world"
# once you've executed some lines, you'll get your greeting in the pane below this one. (that's where all "output" gets "printed" to).
# select the next box, "variables", for more tutorial.

field.core.ui.text.rulers.ExecutedAreas_.stringAtExecution: # once you've executed some lines, you'll get your greeting in the pane below this one. (that's where all "output" gets "printed" to).
# once you've executed some lines, you'll get your greeting in the pane below this one. (that's where all "output" gets "printed" to).

entry.string:
label= """this is a box with code in it, click to select it; then find the window labelled "Text Editor" """ width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# Field uses Python as its default language. So this editor usually contains Python code.
# Python is a dynamic language, so we can just set variables:
a = 10 print a
b = "hello" print b
# (run the lines above by selecting them, or putting the cursor on them and pressing command-return; look for the output below)
# typing 'print' when we want to print a variable gets tired real fast, so in Field you can just press command-/ # try it here: a

label= """and these are two more""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# In the Field environment, variables are global. In the box marked "variables" we made an 'a' and a 'b'. We can still print them here:
print a,b
# Field remembers that "variables" was the box that made 'a' and 'b'. If you try to access 'a' or 'b' and they are undefined, the "variables" box will be automatically executed.
# Python is a complete programming langauge, and there are lots of good tutorials available for learning it, and Field is probably a good tool to use if you want to experiment with the language.
# If you are completely new to programming, you'll probably want to find one of those tutorials now. For people who need a little refresher on Python Syntax, see the "syntax box" below

label= """you make boxes by pressing 'n' or using the right click menu "create new visual element here".

Try making one here: """ width=340 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2()) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1

baseTool( node=Direct(3, 0, "n"), coords=(Rel(None, Vector2(101.0, 320.0), None), ) )
baseTool( node=Direct(0, 0, "n"), coords=(Rel(None, Vector2(58.0, 297.0), None), ) )

label= """

you can change its name (and position, and lots of other things) using the inspector window which looks like this: """ width=300 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2()) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(alignment_v=1) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1

label= """ If you are running out of window space, you can pan the window with the mouse using either the middle mouse button or a drag gesture on a laptop""" width=600 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(alignment_v=1)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# Python has a dynamic type system, so you just make variables up without declaring what kind of things they refer to:
foo = 10 bar = "banana"
x = 10 + foo
# If you are used to Java or Processing that's one of the big differences (In either Procesing or Java you'd have to say "int foo = 10;" rather than "foo = 10".
# You can even change what kind of thing a variable refers to: foo = "more bananas"
# that used to be a number, 10 and now it's a String, "more bananas".
# if you make a mistake, Field gives you an error in the output window: y = 10 + bar # (you can't add 10 to "banana", it doesn't make any sense)
# Of course in Python you can make your own functions: def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a+b
# this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)
# if the line above gives you an error instead of printing 9, make sure you have actually executed the definition of addTwoNumbers before calling "print addTwoNumbers". It's not enough to have written the code, you need to actually execute it before Field really knows about it. This gives you a lot of control over what happens, when.
# White-space is important when we wrote "def addTwoNumbers(a,b):" the next line was indented with a tab. Python pays attention to these indents to work out where the definition of addTwoNumbers ends. Python can uses spaces or tabs, but Field would really prefer if you used tabs. That's another big difference between Python and other languages you might know.
# Other Python things ---
# lists myList = [1,2,3, "banana"] print myList
myList[0] = 5 print myList
# tuples (like lists, but once created they can't change) myTuple = (1,2,3, "banana")
# dictionaries (forms relationship between keys (like the words in the dictionary) and values (their definitions)) myDictionary = { "hello" : "there", 3: "everybody"} print myDictionary["hello"] # prints "there" print myDictionary[3] # prints "everybody"
# and you can delete things from lists and dictionaries (but not tuples): del myList[1] del myDictionary["hello"]
# iterating over a list looks like this: for n in myList: print "an item", n
# or you can do this: for n in range(0, len(myList)): print "an item", myList[n]
# or even this (kind of): print [("an item", n) for n in myList]
# if none of this is making any sense at all, it's time to go google yourself a Python tutorial there are lots of nice ones out there. You can work through your tutorial inside Field itself, just make some more boxes to put the code you type into.

field.core.ui.text.rulers.ExecutedAreas_.stringAtExecution:
# lists myList = [1,2,3, "banana"] print myList
myList[0] = 5 print myList
# tuples (like lists, but once created they can't change myTuple = (1,2,3, "banana")
# dictionaries myDictionary = { "hello" : "there", 3: "everybody"} print myDictionary["hello"] print myDictionary[3]
for n in myList: print n
print [("an item", n) for n in myList]

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a,b
#this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a+b
# this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

entry.string:
# Since Field is all about running code, it gives you lots of different ways of doing it
# We've already seen one command-return executes the current line or currently selected text. Select all of these lines and try it one more time:
print "hello world" print "isn't running code wonderful"
# after you've command-returned this code you'll see something appear in the left margin of this text editor. This is an execution trace it shows you what bits of this editor you have selected and run. This is useful for remembering what you are doing. The marker grows and shrinks appropriately as you add and remove text in the editor.
# Best of all, if you option-click on one of these traces you'll execute this code again. That way you don't have to keep carefully selecting bits of the editor. You can even assign keyboard shortcuts to traces try right clicking on a trace.
# To run all of the code in the editor press command-zero print "and this will get run as well"

field.core.ui.text.rulers.ExecutedAreas_.stringAtExecution: print [("an item", n) for n in myList]

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a,b
#this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a+b
# this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

entry.string:
# What about animation? To animate something you often need to run code over and over again. You certainly cant sit there and hit command-return over and over to make an animation.
# Field differenciates between running code (command-return and its friends) and "animating" a box
# say we want to call this function over and over again:
def doItOverAndOverAgain(): print "I'm running"
# Field uses a special variable called '_r' to determine what functions to call _r = doItOverAndOverAgain
# to "start" this box we can option-click on the box itself using the mouse. This executes all of the code in this box and then looks to see if _r has been set to anything. If it has, Field knows what to do.
# This makes it turn green to tell us that it's running. It will run as long as we are holding down the mouse button. An option will pop up above the mouse the lets you keep it running forever
# To stop it, option click on it again this will give you an option to stop this box running.
# As many boxes can be running as you like.

field.core.ui.text.rulers.ExecutedAreas_.stringAtExecution: print [("an item", n) for n in myList]

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a,b
#this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a+b
# this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

entry.string:
# there are a few things that _r can be set to. We've already seen one a function. Here's another:
def start(): print "I'm starting"
def goOn(): print "I'm still going"
def stop(): print "That's it, I'm done"
_r = start, goOn, stop
#Now Field will call 'start' once, then 'goOn' while this box is running, and 'stop' when you elect to stop this box. Try it.
#If you want to know more about what _r can do, select this text here:
# VisualElementLifecycles
# and right-click and select "search over OpenEndedGroup.com". That's how you search the online Field documentation site.

field.core.ui.text.rulers.ExecutedAreas_.stringAtExecution: print [("an item", n) for n in myList]

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a,b
#this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)

def addTwoNumbers(a,b): return a+b
# this will print 9 print addTwoNumbers(5, 4)
